title: Infoblox Cloud Data Connector
descriptionMarkdown: The Infoblox Cloud Data Connector allows you to easily connect your Infoblox BloxOne data with Azure Sentinel.  By connecting your logs to Azure Sentinel, you can take advantage of search & correlation, alerting, and threat intelligence enrichment for each log.

graphQueries.baseQuery:
CommonSecurityLog
| where DeviceVendor == "Infoblox" and DeviceProduct == "Data Connector"

sampleQueries.description: Return all BloxOne Threat Defense (TD) logs
sampleQueries.query:
CommonSecurityLog
| where DeviceVendor == "Infoblox" and DeviceProduct == "Data Connector"
 | where DeviceEventClassID has_cs "RPZ"

CommonSecurityLog
| where DeviceVendor == "Infoblox" and DeviceProduct == "Data Connector"
 | where DeviceEventClassID has_cs "DNS Response"

sampleQueries.description: Return all Category Filters security events
sampleQueries.query:
CommonSecurityLog
| where DeviceVendor == "Infoblox" and DeviceProduct == "Data Connector"
 | where DeviceEventClassID has_cs "RPZ"
 | where AdditionalExtensions contains "InfobloxRPZ=CAT_"

sampleQueries.description: Return Top 10 TD Domains Hit Count
sampleQueries.query:
CommonSecurityLog
| where DeviceVendor == "Infoblox" and DeviceProduct == "Data Connector"
 | where DeviceEventClassID has_cs "RPZ" 
| summarize count() by DestinationDnsDomain 
| top 10 by count_ desc

sampleQueries.description: Return Top 10 TD Source IPs Hit Count
sampleQueries.query:
CommonSecurityLog
| where DeviceVendor == "Infoblox" and DeviceProduct == "Data Connector"
 | where DeviceEventClassID has_cs "RPZ" 
| summarize count() by SourceIP 
| top 10 by count_ desc

dataTypes.name: CommonSecurityLog (InfobloxCDC)
dataTypes.lastDataReceivedQuery:
CommonSecurityLog
| where DeviceVendor == "Infoblox" and DeviceProduct == "Data Connector"
 | summarize Time = max(TimeGenerated)
| where isnotempty(Time)

value:
CommonSecurityLog
| where DeviceVendor == "Infoblox"
| where DeviceProduct == "Data Connector"
| summarize LastLogReceived = max(TimeGenerated)
| project IsConnected = LastLogReceived > ago(30d)

instructionSteps.title: 1. Linux Syslog agent configuration
instructionSteps.description:
Install and configure the Linux agent to collect your Common Event Format (CEF) Syslog messages and forward them to Azure Sentinel.

> Notice that the data from all regions will be stored in the selected workspace

innerSteps.title: 1.1 Select or create a Linux machine
innerSteps.description: Select or create a Linux machine that Azure Sentinel will use as the proxy between your security solution and Azure Sentinel this machine can be on your on-prem environment, Azure or other clouds.

innerSteps.title: 1.2 Install the CEF collector on the Linux machine
innerSteps.description:
Install the Microsoft Monitoring Agent on your Linux machine and configure the machine to listen on the necessary port and forward messages to your Azure Sentinel workspace. The CEF collector collects CEF messages on port 514 TCP.

> 1. Make sure that you have Python on your machine using the following command: python -version.

> 2. You must have elevated permissions (sudo) on your machine.

instructionSteps.title: 2. Configure Infoblox BloxOne to send Syslog data to the Infoblox Cloud Data Connector to forward to the Syslog agent
instructionSteps.description:
Follow the steps below to configure the Infoblox CDC to send BloxOne data to Azure Sentinel via the Linux Syslog agent. This Sentinel data connector assumes an Infoblox Cloud Data Connector on-prem host has already been created and configured in the Infoblox Cloud Services Portal (CSP). 

1. Log into the Infoblox Cloud Services Portal (CSP).
2. Navigate to **Manage > Data Connector**.
3. Click the **Destination Configuration** tab at the top.
4. Click **Create > Syslog**. 
 - **Name**: Give the new Destination a meaningful **name**, such as **Azure-Sentinel-Destination**.
 - **Description**: Optionally give it a meaningful **description**.
 - **State**: Set the state to **Enabled**.
 - **Format**: Set the format to **CEF**.
 - **FQDN/IP**: Enter the IP address of the Linux device on which the Linux agent is installed.
 - **Port**: Leave the port number at **514**.
 - **Protocol**: Leave the protocol at **TCP**.
 - Click **Save & Close**.
5. Click the **Traffic Flow Configuration** tab at the top.
6. Click **Create**.
 - **Name**: Give the new Traffic Flow a meaningful **name**, such as **Azure-Sentinel-Flow**.
 - **Description**: Optionally give it a meaningful **description**. 
 - **State**: Set the state to **Enabled**. 
 - Expand the **CDC Enabled Host** section. 
    - **On-Prem Host**: Select your desired on-prem host for which the Data Connector service is enabled. 
 - Expand the **Source Configuration** section.  
    - **Source**: Select **BloxOne Cloud Source**. 
    - Select all desired **log types** you wish to collect. 
 - Expand the **Destination Configuration** section.  
    - Select the **Destination** you just created. 
 - Click **Save & Close**. 
7. Allow the configuration some time to activate.
